{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3546707,"name":"Gerran Hullah","username":"ghullah","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/6f9a4e/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-03T23:58:46.457Z","cooked":"

Hi CD,

We are using a REV MAXPlanetary Gearbox this season to drive our climber. After an output stage failure we noticed that the rated max torque for the 1/2" Hex Output Stage is 250 Nm. Given the NEO’s stall torque is 2.6 Nm, this would imply that for every MAXPlanetary Gearbox ratio combination greater than ~96:1 (100, 108, 125, 135, 144), if the motor were to stall, the output stage would fail. Is this a correct interpretation of these charts, and do y’all encounter problems using output stages at these ratios?

Any feedback would be appreciated!

MAXPlanetary Product Page:
https://www.revrobotics.com/maxplanetary-system-kit/

Load Ratings:
https://docs.revrobotics.com/ion-build-system/motion/maxplanetary-system/load-ratings

it is definitely possible to destroy the output stage by overdriving it. the failure mode we saw was breaking the casting near the mounting bolts. use a current limit!

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-03-04T04:13:14.302Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":147,"readers_count":146,"score":29.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":494107,"topic_slug":"maxplanetary-hex-output-stage-failure-question","display_username":"joel truher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53190,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/maxplanetary-hex-output-stage-failure-question/494107/2","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3546972,"name":"Eliot Dunn","username":"Eliot","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/eliot/{size}/207280_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-04T04:27:38.473Z","cooked":"

While a neo with no current limit will give that much torque, but if you put a 60A current limit the NEO gives ~1 Nm at stall. Most/all teams should be putting current limits on their motors.

reca.lc

ReCalc

ReCalc - a collaboration focused mechanical design calculator.

true. also don’t forget the momentum of the motor itself: it’s a heavy mass of steel and copper whizzing at 6000 rpm, so if you hit the hard stop at full speed, with a zillion-to-one reduction, even with a current limit, something’s going to break.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-03-04T05:17:04.210Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":98,"readers_count":97,"score":19.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":494107,"topic_slug":"maxplanetary-hex-output-stage-failure-question","display_username":"joel truher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53190,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/maxplanetary-hex-output-stage-failure-question/494107/4","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3547666,"name":"","username":"Alex_Y","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-04T22:38:24.688Z","cooked":"

Dynamic loads are a thing and can cause early failure. The robot is not only climbing, but accelerating and swinging which causes increased stresses that are difficult to predict. Current limits won’t fully protect you from dynamic loads because your gearbox and motor have inertia to them that can cause these high forces to exist for long enough to cause damage.
